channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Maneuvers to Try to Avoid Devastating Rail Strike
item.description: The Biden administration is considering executive action to try to avoid a shutdown of the nation’s rail network that would harm the economy ahead of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
item.category: International Assn of Machinists and Aerospace Workers
item.media:description: American railways are responsible for transporting much of the chemicals, automobiles, metals, grain and oil that moves around the continent.

item.title: How a Rail Strike Could Reinvigorate Supply Chain Disruption
item.description: If freight trains stop rolling, the result could be chaos for business, shortages for consumers, and fresh momentum for rising prices.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of railroad workers have threatened to go on strike across the country as early as Friday.

item.title: In Russian Border City of Belgorod, the Ukraine War Feels Real
item.description: In Belgorod, 25 miles from Ukraine, recent losses by Russia’s military have brought home the reality of the war in a way not present elsewhere in the country.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: In Belgorod, Russia, military vehicles marked with the letters Z, V and O, which have become symbols of the Russian invasion, ride through the city.

item.title: Russian missiles hit a dam in southern Ukraine, sparking fears of flooding.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian missile attack on a dam caused flooding in the industrial city of Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: An Eastern City Under Attack Wonders How Far Ukraine’s Offensive Can Go
item.description: Bakhmut residents who have endured relentless shelling by the Russians watch the Ukrainian forces’ recent victories and weigh whether to stay or to flee.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A tank passing through the center of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Pakistan Suffers Record Flooding, Turning Villages Into Islands
item.description: The flooding has displaced more than 33 million people, submerging vast areas of Pakistan that are likely to take months to dry out.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boat operators from other regions have come to Sindh Province to make money as ferries for stranded townspeople. They use power lines as landmarks.

item.title: Patagonia Founder Gives Away the Company to Fight Climate Change
item.description: Yvon Chouinard has forfeited ownership of the company he founded 49 years ago. The profits will now be used to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Natalie Behring for The New York Times

item.title: Queen’s Coffin Passes Through London Landmarks to Westminster Hall
item.description: King Charles III, his siblings and his sons followed the gun carriage carrying the monarch to Westminster Hall, where she will lie in state.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The procession was one of the most solemn of the public rituals marking the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: The Mystery Behind the Crime Wave at 312 Riverside Drive
item.description: For years, the police have received thousands of 911 calls reporting fights, murders, bombs and hostage situations at the same address. But officers never find victims or make arrests. Why?
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Sarah Blesener for The New York Times

item.title: In Dramatic Shift, Right-Wing Bloc Wins Slim Majority in Sweden
item.description: Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson said on Wednesday that she would resign. Despite the success of the far-right Sweden Democrats, they will influence but are not expected to be formally part of the governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Fredrik Sandberg/TT News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The new government is expected to be led by Ulf Kristersson, head of the Moderates, part of a right-wing bloc that won 176 of 349 seats in Parliament.

item.title: Sweden’s Far Right Just Made History. Is It the Country’s Future?
item.description: The anti-immigration Sweden Democrats beat out more moderate right-wing parties in a country famed for liberal governance. It is the latest example of the right’s staying power across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Jimmie Akesson, the leader of the far-right Sweden Democrats party, at a gathering in Stockholm on Sunday.

item.title: How a Spreader of Voter Fraud Conspiracy Theories Became a Star
item.description: For more than a decade, Catherine Engelbrecht, a Texas mom turned election-fraud crusader, has sown doubts about ballots and voting. Her patience has paid off.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

item.title: How Jomboy Media Rose to Power on ‘Good Vibes Only’
item.description: Jimmy O’Brien’s videos breaking down major events turned Jomboy Media into a big business, but O’Brien still sees himself as a fan. “I don’t plan on changing.”
item.dc:creator: Zach Schonbrun and Desiree Rios

item.title: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
item.description: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lines from President Biden’s teleprompter during a speech in Maryland in August.

item.title: China Is Running Covert Operations That Could Seriously Overwhelm Us
item.description: The West isn’t nearly prepared enough for the scale and complexity of China’s all-of-nation covert offensive.
item.dc:creator: Nigel Inkster

item.title: Lindsey Graham’s Unbelievably Cruel Abortion Ban
item.description: Either he doesn’t know how pregnancy works, or he doesn’t care.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: Why Aren’t You Voting in Your Financial Self-Interest?
item.description: The conflict between elites and populists may not be what it seems.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall

item.title: Ukraine’s Achievement Is Biden’s, Too
item.description: As Russian troops flee their positions, now is the time to press the military advantage.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier waves to passing buses near the recaptured village of Verbivka, Ukraine.

item.title: China Is Writing the Story of the Climate Future
item.description: But what story is it?
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: What It Took for Stella Levi to Talk About the Holocaust
item.description: How a chance meeting with one of the last Jews of Rhodes changed me.
item.dc:creator: Michael Frank

item.title: Putin Will Make People Choose Between Heating and Eating This Winter
item.description: To defeat petro-Putinism in Europe, U.S. energy policy has to be the arsenal of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A rail strike would disrupt the transport of a vast range of goods, such as agricultural crops and lumber.

item.title: The Perseverance of Megan Thee Stallion
item.description: The rapper’s rise has been accompanied by outside noise. How has she grown on record, and how have extra-musical narratives shaped her career?

item.title: Have You Recently Purchased Your First Gun? We Want to Hear About It.
item.description: We’re interested in hearing from people who have decided to buy a gun for the first time in the past few years.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Handguns for sale at a store in Atlanta, Ga., in June.

item.title: Let’s Talk About E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Ragtime’
item.description: Join the writer Jonathan Dee in a virtual conversation on Sept. 15 about the 1975 novel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: California Files Antitrust Lawsuit Against Amazon
item.description: Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, said the retailer punishes companies that offer lower prices on other websites.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and David McCabe
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California officials say Amazon is punishing retailers that offer lower prices on alternative sites on the internet.

item.title: Oil Executives Privately Contradicted Public Statements on Climate, Files Show
item.description: The documents, subpoenaed in a House investigation of climate disinformation, show company leaders contravening industry commitments.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: A Shell station in Houston. An internal email in 2020 said the company’s announcement of a pathway to net zero emissions had “nothing to do with” its business plans.

item.title: Mother Charged With Murdering 3 Children Who Drowned in Coney Island
item.description: Erin Merdy had been in a long-running custody fight and faced eviction before the Monday killings.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police at the scene where 3 children drowned off Coney Island Beach near West 35th St. in Brooklyn on Monday.

item.title: Rommy Hunt Revson, Creator of the Scrunchie, Dies at 78
item.description: A former nightclub singer, she developed the simple ornamental hair tie that quickly became a ubiquitous accessory.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Rommy Hunt Revson in an undated photo. In 1986, she received a patent for a hairband made of fabric and elastic that came to be known as the Scrunchie, a hugely popular accessory in the 1980s and ’90s.

item.title: What Is Brain Fog and How Can I Treat It?
item.description: Researchers are just beginning to understand the cognitive dysfunction that some people experience with Covid-19 and a range of other health issues.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Processed Meat and Health Risks: What to Know
item.description: Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Should You Put on Sunscreen or Foundation First?
item.description: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
item.dc:creator: Caira Blackwell
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
item.description: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Take on an Empty Stomach.’ How Do You Know When Your Stomach Is Empty?
item.description: Two hours after eating is a crude rule of thumb. A more accurate answer depends on the drugs you are taking and your medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.

item.title: A New Look at a Diane Arbus Exhibition, 50 Years Later
item.description: David Zwirner Gallery in New York is restaging the photographer’s 1972 retrospective.
item.dc:creator: M.H. Miller
